The text introduces “meta−d′” as the rater’s notional type-1 sensitivity and uses it as “an influential and attractive” way to assess metacognitive sensitivity.
“It is then possible to create a metacognitive efficiency measure … the so-called M-ratio, which is meta−d′ /d′.”
“meta−I is a model-agnostic measure of metacognitive sensitivity which quantifies the mutual information between r and c.”
“We write meta−I r1 = meta−I / meta−I(d′)… this normalization has more nearly equated the estimates of metacognitive efficiency.”
“We call the resulting measure of metacognitive efficiency meta−I r2… this also accounts well for the fact that… metacognitive sensitivity cannot be high.”
